body.p: In the previous chapters, we built a solid foundation for AI coding assistants: multi-provider integration, dependency injection, and service management. Now we face a critical question: How do we enable AI to actually DO things?
An AI that can only chat is like a mechanic who can diagnose problems but can't pick up a wrench. The real power of AI coding assistants comes from their ability to execute actions:

Tool orchestration is the architectural pattern that enables AI agents to interact with the world through well-defined, composable tools. This chapter explores how to design, implement, and orchestrate tools that are:

ul.li: Safe - Tools require approval for destructive operations
Efficient - Parallel execution and result caching
Reliable - Robust error handling and recovery
Composable - Tools can depend on other tools
Observable - Full visibility into tool execution

body.p: By the end of this chapter, you'll understand:

ol.li: Tool System Architecture - How tools fit into the overall system
Tool Interface Design - Creating clean, composable tool contracts
Tool Implementations - File system, git, and code analysis tools
Dependency Resolution - Building and executing dependency graphs
Parallel Execution - Optimizing performance with concurrency
Result Caching - Avoiding redundant work
Interactive Approval - Safety mechanisms for destructive operations
Error Handling - Graceful degradation and recovery strategies

body.p: AI models excel at understanding natural language and generating text, but they can't directly interact with file systems, execute commands, or modify code. We need a bridge between AI reasoning and real-world actions.
Consider this user request:
body.codeblock: User: "Find all TODO comments in the codebase and create GitHub issues for them"
body.p: To fulfill this request, an AI coding assistant needs to:

ol.li: Search the codebase for TODO comments ( search_code tool)
Read files containing TODOs to get context ( read_file tool)
Extract TODO information and categorize by priority
Create GitHub issues via API ( create_github_issue tool)
Link code locations to the created issues

body.p: Without tools, the AI can only provide instructions. With tools, the AI can execute the entire workflow autonomously.
Tool orchestration provides:

ol.li: Tool Abstraction - Common interface for all tools
Dependency Management - Tools can depend on other tools
Execution Planning - Optimal execution order
Parallel Execution - Run independent tools concurrently
Result Caching - Avoid redundant operations
Safety Mechanisms - Approval workflows for destructive operations
Progress Tracking - Real-time visibility into execution
Error Recovery - Graceful handling of failures

body.p: Now let's implement concrete tools across different categories. We'll build file system tools, git tools, and code analysis tools.

The tool registry is the central catalog of all available tools. It provides: - Tool registration and discovery - Validation that all dependencies exist - Tool lookup by name - Metadata about available tools for AI context
Tools can depend on other tools. For example, edit_file might depend on read_file and write_file. The dependency resolver builds an execution graph and determines the optimal execution order.
Now that we can resolve dependencies, let's implement parallel execution to maximize performance.
Many tools are deterministic - given the same inputs, they produce the same outputs. Result caching avoids redundant work by storing and reusing tool results.
Now we bring it all together. The Tool Orchestrator is the main component that coordinates tool execution.
For destructive operations, we need user approval. Let's implement a robust approval system.
Robust error handling is crucial for production systems. Let's implement comprehensive error recovery.
In this chapter, we've built a complete tool orchestration system with:

ol.li: Tool Interface - Clean, declarative contracts for all tools
Tool Implementations - File system, git, and code analysis tools
Tool Registry - Central catalog with dependency validation
Dependency Resolution - DAG construction and topological sorting
Parallel Execution - Concurrent execution with dependency tracking
Result Caching - Avoid redundant work for deterministic operations
Tool Orchestrator - Main coordinator integrating all components
Interactive Approval - Safety mechanisms for destructive operations
Error Handling - Categorization, retry logic, and graceful degradation
